member.name: T:Google.Cloud.Firestore.FieldValue
member.summary: A static class providing properties and methods to represent sentinel values. Sentinel values are special values where the client-side value is not part of the document modification sent to the server. A property decorated with can specify an additional attribute to indicate that it's a sentinel value, such as a, or the sentinel values returned by the members of this class can be used directly as values to be serialized (for example, in anonymous types), and they will be handled directly by the serialization mechanism.

member.name: P:Google.Cloud.Firestore.FirestoreChangeListener.ListenerTask
member.summary: A task that will complete when the listen operation finishes.
member.remarks: If a cancellation token provided by the caller (either when starting to listen or when calling ) is canceled, the task will finish in a state of . The task will finish in a state of if any other kind of exception was thrown, including any non-retriable RPC exceptions. The task will finish in a state of if the listener stopped gracefully.

member.remarks: This method must only be called once per listener.
member.param: A cancellation token to cancel a callback if one is in progress.
member.returns: The task to indicate listener completion. This returns the same as .

member.name: T:Google.Cloud.Firestore.IFirestoreConverter`1
member.summary: Custom converter used during serialization and deserialization.

remarks.para: This can be specified using to use the custom converter for all values of the attributed type, or using to use the custom converter for a single property. The latter approach can also be used to allow for conversion of types you don't control (e.g. to serialize properties as strings).

This interface is never passed a null value and should never return a null value. Null values are transparently handled by the serialization framework; if a document contains a null value, that will always be deserialized to a null reference (or null value of a nullable value type).

Converters express their conversions in terms of regular .NET types: strings, integers, lists, dictionaries and so on. The result of serializing an object of type is then processed by the default serialization handling into the Firestore protocol buffer representation. Deserialization works the same way: first the Firestore protocol buffer representation is converted into .NET types in the default manner for this library, and the result is passed to the converter. Note that this means there can be asymmetry between serialization and deserialization: if the method returns an , deserializing the result will involve the method receiving an value as that's the default .NET representation of a Firestore integer.

Converters that intend to convert objects into top-level documents should return a string-keyed dictionary of values from . On deserialization, will be passed a value implementing with a key type of and a value type of .

member.typeparam: The type of object to convert.

member.name: M:Google.Cloud.Firestore.IFirestoreConverter`1.ToFirestore(`0)
member.summary: Converts a value to its Firestore representation.
member.param: The value to convert. When called by Google.Cloud.Firestore, this will never be null.
member.returns: The converted value. Must not be null.

member.name: M:Google.Cloud.Firestore.Query.OrderBy(System.String)
member.summary: Adds an additional ascending ordering by the specified path.

remarks.para: Unlike LINQ's OrderBy method, this call adds additional subordinate orderings to any additionally specified. So query.OrderBy("foo").OrderBy("bar") is similar to a LINQ query.OrderBy(x => x.Foo).ThenBy(x => x.Bar).
This method cannot be called after a start/end cursor has been specified with , , or .

member.param: The dot-separated field path to order by. Must not be null or empty.
member.returns: A new query based on the current one, but with the additional specified ordering applied.

member.name: T:Google.Cloud.Firestore.AugmentedValue
member.summary: This is like google.firestore.v1beta1.Value, but with extra "hidden" fields. We can convert between Value and AugmentedValue via serialization without losing information, which lets us "hide" information related to sentinel values (delete, server timestamps, array operations) within a regular Value object. However, such values should never be transmitted over the wire. They are purely implementation details to allow information to flow through a Value-oriented interface.
